Mr Cookman quoted Maundrell for the size of the enormous Cedar of Lebanon, and spoke of what kings would do in the Millennium; if there should be kings; at that time, which was very doubtful.— The hall was more crowded than I had seen it for many years.— I met Mr John Taliaferro there— A very heavy thunder shower prevented my attendance at Church this afternoon. The lightning yesterday struck a barn not far distant from the Capitol, and the barn was burnt down— In the hurricane of this day fortnight a black woman was struck dead by a thunderbolt, in the African church on the brow of the Capitol hill.
27— V. Monday

It was 11. O’Clock before I reached the Capitol, and I had barely time to write out the amendments to be proposed to the Revenue Bill, and take them to Mr Frost in the Clerk’s Office with directions to have them printed this day, before the Meeting of the House— Governor Lincoln has returned from his visit home and resumed his seat which I have occupied during his absence— I had called before going to the Capitol at the Office of the National Intelligencer and given to Mr Gales Stanbury’s part of the report of my remarks last week upon the proposed Resolution to abolish the Committee on public expenditures.— This was a petition day—but no petitions were presented— Campbell of South Carolina moved to reconsider the vote of Saturday that the report and testimony upon the fray between Bynum and Rice Garland should be printed— After some discussion the motion to reconsider was rejected by yeas and nays 9 to 143. Garland made a very handsome apology to the house for the violence of language and action used by him in the conflict with Bynum; who now stood mute— The consideration of the Report was postponed till to-morrow. Sweeney had asked leave to offer a Bill providing for the appointment of District attornies by the Courts, and for limiting their profits and fees, which had been refused—the refusal was now reconsidered—the bill introduced and referred to the Committee on the judiciary.— The Morning hour was gone— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Casey in the Chair and the civil and diplomatic appropriation Bill— Dillett took three more hours to finish his Speech—a regular oration in Sections—chiefly upon the sub treasury; with episodes upon Banks and Banking, the currency, the Tariff and abolition— Waddy Thompson told me that in Alabama Dillett is esteemed a prodigy of eloquence— And his Oration of Saturday and this day was very eloquent— Stanly then followed, and Bell, and Dromgoole who gave notice that he would henceforth insist upon the strict enforcement of the rule of relevancy in debate— Proffit hoped the Committee would proceed with the Bill between nine and ten O’Clock this Evening he would begin a most eloquent Speech of an hour and a half— I said I too was labouring with a Speech; but as it would take time, I would not make it upon this Bill, the passage of which I had determined from the day of its introduction into the Committee I had determined not to delay so much as one quarter of an hour— I was loudly called to go on but said no— I would make it upon some other bill—a desultory debate followed upon sundry motions to strike out various items of the Bill till near 9 O’Clock when Proffit made his speech of an hour and a half. After him, Goode of Ohio and Ogle successively attempted to make speeches, but were called to order for irrelevancy; pronounced out of order by the Chairman, from whose decisions there were appeals, and no Quorum to decide them— The Committee then rose and reported to the house, no Quorum— Motion to adjourn Yeas and Nays—a bare Quorum answer and refuse to adjourn— The quorum go into Committee again and in five minutes another question of order is started upon, which no quorum is found to vote and the same tedious round is again gone through— There were three calls of the House ordered and superseded; and at last, an order to the Sergeant at arms
28. Tuesday

to go for the Absentees and bring them in custody to the house. Immediately after this order, Graves moved a reconsideration of it; which was some time debated and refused— It was then half past 3 of Tuesday Morning Linn Banks urged them to adjourn, and told them it would be six O’Clock before they could bring in absent members enough to make a Quorum— I told him he might safely say it would be seven— While the order was being executed I myself left the hall came home went to bed precisely as the clock struck 4. rose again at 7. breakfasted, and returned to the House about half past 8. part of the absentees had been brought up, and were successively called by the Speaker to account for their absence.— They had passed an order that the members who after answering to their names at the first call should leave the Hall, should leave the hall, should be included among the absentees to be taken into custody— Several of that number were so brought in called to answer, and ordered to be discharged with or without payment of fees— I was myself one of that number, but the order for taking them into custody had been rescinded, after having been executed upon Albert Smith, before I returned, so that my name was not entered as an absentee nor was I called to account for my absence— But 63 members were so called to account 28 were administration men and 35 were whigs— There was at least an equal number of absentees 63 who were not brought in—many absent from the city and several who could not be found.— At a quarter before one in the morning, Duncan moved the call of the house, at a quarter before 12 at Noon, Banks moved to suspend further proceedings in the call and the House went into Committee of the whole again, on the appeal from the Chairman Casey’s decision that Ogle was out of order— The call had taken exactly eleven hours of time during which all other action of the house was suspended— The debate upon the Bill was then resumed, with out allowance for the morning hour, and was continued upon the items of appropriation, till near 7. O’Clock in the Evening; during which snarling party scuffles of an hour or two for each question were held upon the restoration of 3000 dollars for the salary of the Commissioner of Pensions—to reduce the Salaries of all the Executive Officers from the heads of Departments downwards, and especially to abolish or reduce the three lately created branch, mint establishments at Charlotte, North-Carolina—at Dahlonega, Georgia, and at New-Orleans, which are perfectly useless and very expensive— It was curious to see the members of both parties from North-Carolina and Georgia, all except Stanly, bristle up against any diminution of the mint expenses in those States— About 7. O’Clock at the motion of Petrikin the Committee rose and the house adjourned. I walked home and found Mrs. Thornton, Mrs Talbot and her daughter here— They almost immediately retired and we dined— I found myself utterly exhausted—unable to work, and even to think— Charles Fisher said the Virginia election news had made the whigs all drunk with hard cider—
29. V. Wednesday.

Went to the Capitol between 10 and 11. A.M. and examined in the Law Library, Burrows’s and the Term Reports, and Emerigon, for the judicial avowal of the principle that the Courts of Justice of commercial Nations disregard the violation of the revenue Laws, of all others— But Valin is not in the Library—and I had not time to consult Pothier— In the house Edmund Burke, Chairman of the select Committee on the Stationery contracts of the Clerk with Langtree, moved for leave to the Committee to employ a Clerk— Graves moved as an amendment that the six Committees on the expenditures should also have Clerks— And W. Cost Johnson moved again an amendment, Clerks for the Committee on the District of Columbia, and the select Committee on a National foundery. Burke’s resolution was now so top heavy, that he asked leave to withdraw it, but having made it by direction of the Committee he was not allowed to withdraw it, and the whole subject was laid on the table— I asked a division of the question, but the Speaker declared it inadmissible. Govr Lincoln presented a Memorial from William Wright concerning the mode of payment by the Commonwealth’s Bank of Boston of their debt to the United States— It was referred to a select Committee— The report upon the fracas between Bynum and Garland was postponed till Friday—and the civil and diplomatic appropriation Bill was again taken up in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Casey in the chair.— The discussion upon the expediency of abolishing the branch mints, at Charlotte, Dahlonega, and New Orleans was resumed, and debated for several hours.— Stanly produced a Bill of between 2 and 300 dollars for flowers and plants and trees for the mint establishment at Charlotte which caused great discomfiture in the ranks of the Administration democracy.— There was then some collision between Jones of the Ways and Means, and Chapman, the Delegate from Iowa, upon items of appropriation for the expenditures, upon the Government of that territory— When the item of the Salary for the Attorney General came up Stanly read extracts from the report of the Swartwout investigation Committee charging Gilpin then Solicitor of the Treasury with gross negligence in suffering Swartwout’s defalcations to run on for years undetected— Ramsay said he had no confidence in the report of that Committee. Stanly read the concurrence of the turncoat Hopkins, in that report and especially in the censure passed upon Gilpin— Hopkins stood mute— As night came on, the usual failure of a Quorum, calls of the house, questions of order, and abortive motions to adjourn ensued. Mason of Ohio moved that upon calls of the house in future, the name of each member should be called only once, which was agreed to— The practice hitherto has been to call a second time the name of every member not answering when named— Cushing moved an amendment—tending to procure the release of Mackenzie from prison, upon which questions of order were started and discussed till near 11. at Night, when the Committee rose, the house adjourned, and I reached home before Midnight.
30. V:30. Thursday

Professor Jaeger, and Mr Stone the engraver called on me this morning, concerning an American Institute for the natural sciences of which they desire and propose the establishment in this City— The first suggestion of it was made in a Letter from George Flower, an Englishman settled in the State of Illinois, published in the National Intelligencer of last Monday. And in that paper of this day there was a short letter from Mr Stone to Mr Jaeger requesting his views on the subject, and Mr Jaeger’s answer enforcing the proposal of Mr Flower.— They said they had been this morning with the Secretary of War, Mr Poinsett, who was favourable to the object, and would invite a meeting of several persons who take an interest in the pursuits of Science, at his house next Saturday evening to consider and consult together upon the subject. They expressed the hope that I would attend this meeting, which I promised to do unless prevented by indispensable attendance upon the House— The weekly meeting of the Committee of Manufactures was held this morning—present Adams, Mitchell, Tillinghast, Slade, Dromgoole, Davis— Absent Nisbett, Worthington, Eastman— Slade remained only a few minutes, observing that as there was a quorum without him, and he felt unwell, he would withdraw— The Letter from the Secretary of the Treasury, concerning a recent judicial decision that the hempen sacks in which salt is usually imported are free of duty, was read and laid on the table. The memorial from Lewisburg Pennsylvania praying for a revisal of the Tariff for the protection of manufactures, was postponed for further consideration.— At the house Cushing from the Committee of foreign Affairs reported a Bill for carrying into effect the recent Convention with Mexico, and gave notice that he should call it up at an early day for consideration— Motions for printing 5000 extra copies of two Treasury reports were after some discussion laid on the table— Graham moved a suspension of the rules for a resolution to meet after next Monday at 11. A.M. Yeas and nays 91 to 85. not two thirds—lost— Committee of the whole on the Union— Casey Chairman— Civil and diplomatic appropriation Bill— Cushing’s motion for applying 5000 dollars for the personal accommodation of Mackenzie and Rensselaer in prison, was by the reversal 28 to 98 of the decision of the Chair suppressed for irrelevancy. Davis of Indiana moved appropriations for the Cumberland road which started again a long debate, which as usual settled into a presidential electioneering canvas.— Underwood, Waddy Thompson, Everett, Cost Johnson and Briggs argued over again the question of internal improvement pro and con with the usual calls to order for irrelevancy, failures of a quorum; reports of that fact to the house: calls of the house, producing by nominal call a bare quorum then returning into Committee to be found again with out a quorum on the first question requiring a vote— A skirmishing debate on sundry items of the Bill continued till Petrikin moved to increase the appropriation of the Treasury building from 51000 to 105000 dollars and of theOffice from 45000 to 100000 dollars. At about 11. O’Clock, the Committee rose and the house adjourned— Home at Midnight—
